title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. Amendments to title 18, United States Code, restrict former Senators, Members of the House, or elected officers from influencing current members or staff for personal gain. SEC. 3 amends the time limit for Congressional staff under title 18, United States Code. SEC. 4 introduces a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database. SEC. 5 addresses the issue of the lobbyist revolving door to Congress. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress they lobbied for within 6 years. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or Standards of Official Conduct for a compelling national need. Lobbying contacts must be related to legislative business, earmarks, or fundraising to be considered substantial. Contacts related to pending legislative business, solicitation of earmarks or Federal funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising exceeding personal contributions constitute substantial lobbying contacts. Simple social contacts with Members or congressional staff do not qualify as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. A substantial lobbying entity must annually file a list of former lawmakers or congressional staff members they employ, along with job descriptions. The filing required by this section shall contain job descriptions of employees, individuals under contract, or consultants, and their work experience. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will have a database of 'Substantial Lobbying Entities'. Filings will be provided to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for law enforcement oversight. The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for oversight. Substantial lobbying entity refers to an incorporated entity with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
